title.en: Privacy and Data Protection - Ethics, Law, and Information Technology
title.et: Privaatsus ja andmekaitse - eetilised, õiguslikud ja IT aspektid

name.en: Chair of Public Economics and Policy

structural_unit_name.en: Chair of Public Economics and Policy

description.en: The course introduces strategies, theories, instruments, institutions and processes of regulation, related to digitalization. Regulatory approaches will be analyzed from the perspective of different interest groups, initiatives and goals. The course also investigates the evolution of regulation theories and examines the application of various regulatory models and instruments to the problems and opportunities related to digitalization and innovation.
description.et: Kursus tutvustab erinevaid digitaliseerimisega seonduvaid regulatsioonistrateegiaid, teooriaid, instrumente, institutsioone ja protsesse. Digitaliseerimise ja küberturvalisusega seotud küsimusi vaadeldakse läbi erinevate huvi(gruppi)de, initsiatiivide ja eesmärkide. Samuti uuritakse regulatsiooniteooria arengut ja erinevate regulatsioonimudelite ja -vahendite kasutamist seoses digitaliseerimise ja innovatsiooniga kaasnevate probleemide ja võimalustega.

objectives.en: Next to economic growth, new rights and freedoms, and solutions to socially important problems, the development of technology and digital transformation are also accompanied by a number of complex problems, the solution of which requires regulation. The aim of the course is to increase students' readiness to recognize such problems, to analyze them based on previous regulatory models and experience, and to see possible solutions to the respective problems in both politics and law. During the course, a comprehensive overview of the legal, ethical and political issues related to digitalization and cyber security and the possibilities of approaching them in Europe and the world will be given.
objectives.et: Digitaalne transformatsioon, andmemajandus ja küberohud on arenenud infoühiskondades tekitanud vajaduse uute ja senisest tõhusamate regulatsioonimudelite järele. Samas on kasvamas innovatsiooni, andmetöötluse ja info- ja kommunikatsiooni tehnoloogia kasutamisega seonduvad erimeelsused eri maailmavaadetega ja eri arengutasemega, aga ka majanduslikult konkureerivate riikide vahel. Aine eesmärgiks on toetada strateegilist ja laiapõhjalist lähenemist digireguleerimisele.

learning_outcomes.en: *	understands the main areas and evolutionary phases of digital regulation;
learning_outcomes.et: *	omab ülevaadet digiregulatsiooni peamistest valdkondadest ja arenguetappidest;

learning_outcomes.en: *	knows contemporary regulation theory and is able to apply it to the problems related to digitalization, innovation, data economy and cybersecurity;
learning_outcomes.et: *	tunneb kaasaegseid regulatsiooniteooriaid ja oskab neid rakendada digitaliseerimise, andmemajanduse ja küberjulgeolekuga seonduvatele probleemidele;

learning_outcomes.en: *	is prepared to detect opportunities for effective regulation and find common ground between diverging regulatory preferences.
learning_outcomes.et: *	omab ettevalmistust regulatsioonivõimaluste tuvastamiseks ja erinevate regulatsioonieelistuste vahel ühisosa leidmiseks.

notes.et: Individual lessons take place on weeks 29, 31 and 33 (Thursdays 12:15-13:45) on zoom. These will be open to pre-registered students and will cover additional topics like legal drafting, selected court cases related to digital regulation and comparative regulation looking into how other countries deal with digitalization and cybersecurity in their domestic law. Individual lessons also have Q&A sessions that can be used for consultation and feedback purposes.

description.et: Test, 2 x 10% of the final grade, focuses on the legal terminology and concepts.
30 % of the grade, this task requires developing a regulatory response to an ongoing court case or openly observable difference related to digitalization and/or digital innovation.

50% of the final grade, submitted as a draft blog post that details a regulatory strategy related to digitalization and/or digital innovation or critically examines an existing regulatory approach and its efficiency. There are five evaluation criteria of the final paper: clear focus (context, issue, purpose), thorough context assessment (details and evidence), clearly identified alternatives of solving the issue, a thoroughly elaborated solution chosen from the alternatives, and impact assessment.

grade_preconditions.et: Submission of individual and group work according to the deadlines set in Moodle.

grade_evaluation.et:
20% test results
30% case analysis
50% draft blog post

assessment_scale.et: Eristav (A, B, C, D, E, F, mi)
assessment_scale.en: differentiated (A, B, C, D, E, F, not present)

resources.mandatory_materials: Lecture slides and reading material provided by the lecturer (see Moodle).
resources.recommended_materials: Reading material referred by the lecturer (see Moodle).

description.et: Governing Digitalization: Main regulatory dilemmas and approaches since the 1950s, current domestic and international governance mechanisms and frameworks, key concepts, discussion of tasks and grading

topic.et: Basics of law in Estonia and in the EU (4h) (10.15-11.45; 12.15-13.45)
Theories of regulation (2h) (10.15-11.45)Regulatory approaches to access to information (2h) (12.15-13.45)
Regulatory design of privacy and personal data protection (4h) (10.15-11.45; 12.15-13.45)
Regulatory approaches to information operations, cyber and hybrid threats (4h) (10.15-11.45; 12.15-13.45)
Regulatory strategies for supporting and countering innovation: selected raw materials, AI (4h) (10.15-11.45; 12.15-13.45)
Governing digitalization: corporate, domestic and international prospects (4h) (10.15-11.45; 12.15-13.45)

audience.et: Entrepreneurship in Economic Policymaking, Contemporary Economy master students and micro-degree students
